Comments_List: Long run and short run models in macroeconomics.

The course provides a general overview of macroeconomics with a somewhat mathematical foundation. I learned mostly about long-run models (economic growth over the long term) and short-run models (business cycles).

I developed knowledge of the theories of long-run growth such as Solow, Romer, and Malthus; explanations for the differences in economic growth in developing and developed countries; the classical dichotomy and inflation, a model of consumption and investment, the aggregate demand-aggregate supply framework, the monetary response of the Federal Reserve, and inequality. Overall, I feel that I have learned a broad array of macroeconomic concepts that have increased my economic knowledge and confidence in my ability to continue further in this subject area.
Long-run growth theories (Solow and Romer); Short-run model (IS-MP model and AS-AD model); few lectures on inequality
I learned all about the Solow/Romer models in the long run, the Malthusian model, AS/AD curves in the short run, utility maximization, and the Phillips Curve.
More knowledge of economics.
General knowledge about macroeconomics with an emphasis on the quantitative side beyond the scope of the introductory course.

Intermediate Macroeconomics is a more mathematical extension of introductory macroeconomics. You learn the mechanics behind the short and long run models of economic development. The professor, Michael Peters, tries very hard to apply these concepts to the real world, so I felt as though I got more out of this economics class in terms of global relevance compared to others in the major.
A continuation of intro macro and its skills but now with more understanding of the math behind the models

I further developed my knowledge and skills in macroeconomics, and in particular, began to understand the dynamic between monetary and fiscal policy, and their interaction with GDP, inflation and rates.
It moves from talking about long-run growth (models from Solow, Romer, and Malthus) to short-run fluctuations (the IS-MP model, AS-AD model, and their components such as investment and consumption).
Modern macroeconomic theory discussing measurement, development, long run growth models, short run fluctuations, inflation, and monetary policy.

We covered a lot of models about long-run growth (Classical, Solow, Romer, Malthus), short-run fluctuations (AS-AD framework), and topics such as GDP, consumption, investment, monetary policy, inflation, etc. I also learned how the concepts we learned could be applied to/found in the real world. Professor Peters would start each lecture with an "In the News" segment. He would find a news article (and encouraged us to send him ones we found as well) about macroeconomics topics in the real world. For example, we covered topics such as Brexit, the Green New Deal, how technology is affecting unemployment, etc.
Good understanding of short- and long-run macroeconomic phenomena, with an ability to apply theoretical principles to economic news and data.
Macroeconomics.

I really learned about key economic models that are used when predicting economic growth, which I found very interesting. I also learned about how the economy operates in the short run and long run, and learned about developmental economics.

I learned how to view, manipulate, and analyze economic theories and models to understand the macroeconomy. He made me love economics and all the interesting and policy-relevant questions macroeconomic theory poses to our world.
I learned how to contextualize broad macroeconomic concepts, and think about economic news more critically using the models and frameworks we discussed in ECON 122.
You learn a lot about macroeconomic theory and how to apply it.
I learned about monetary and fiscal policy, the business cycle, and the general workings of the macroeconomy.
I developed a good understanding of how the different components of the macro economy interact, and how to analyze real world events using the models in class.
Macro Economics as well as brief insights into important economic events at the time.

I learned about various theories of consumption and how each one offers its own interpretation of macroeconomic trends. I also gained several math-based skills that can be used to derive expressions and equations.
I learned a lot about macroeconomics as well as how to interpret economics information that I read in current events.

This course was conceptually similar to intro macro, but with some extra nuances on the same basic models. I probably know a fair about about macroeconomics right now, but I feel like I'm probably going to forget it all in the next 6 months.
A more advanced knowledge of macroeconomic theory.
Slides should be improved.
Well organized.
Only one practice test per midterm/final is too few! The class is very slow and many of the topics could be covered in half the class period. Love Professor Peters though!

A strength of this course was the constant tying-back of concepts we covered in class to news stories, as it truly emphasized the practicality and significance of the content we were learning. Too often in economics classes, we get bogged down in mathematical equations and forget that the models we study have relevance to the real world, but this class did an excellent job of balancing both the nitty-gritty mathematical details and the real-world examples. The main weakness of this course was the heavy weight placed on all of the exams, particularly the final which was worth 50 percent of the final grade. I believe that having so much of a weight on one exam is unfair, and it might be better for there to be two midterms for the class in order to spread out the weighting of each exam.

Strengths: Professor Peters tries to engage his students during the lectures through frequent questions, which I appreciate.
Weaknesses: More preparation for exams could be offered.
This is a rigorous course that well prepares students for Macroeconomics.

Strengths: Existing sections allowed for study groups to form, which helped with the challenging problem sets.

Cons: The Slides have a lot of hidden information in terms for assumption for models, and do not provide enough information to explain the nuances of macroeconomics. In lecture, the professor only hints at these assumptions and hidden calculations through anecdotes or casual statements, which makes it incredibly difficult to catch and understand.

Strengths: Prof Peters is great
Weakness: TAs are really bad

Strengths: the material is very interesting and applies to what I read every day in the news. Professor Peters demonstrates this by bringing in news articles to class often. The problem sets and exams provide new real-world scenarios to apply the theory and skills we've learned in class.

I really wanted to like this class, but ultimately felt that it was difficult to tie concepts together. For example, I didn't really get how the separate lectures on consumption, investment, the Phillips Curve and so on ties together, until the very last lecture on the AS-AD model when Prof. Peters provided a summary. I wish that this overview was done earlier, so we know how each component fits into the larger framework. I think the lectures themselves are also very big-picture and I wish we spent more time talking about the math (and how economic intuition connects to it), because this was mostly tested on the exam and we need to get the math part right to be able to adapt the models to new situations. 

The exam questions also felt very tricky and didn't really test how well we studied, but how fast we can change our models to suit the modifications on the exam questions. The True/False questions also tend to be tricky and test the finer details of the concepts in class. Perhaps this was the professor's aim, but it really disadvantages students who might've prepared a lot practicing PSET questions or reviewing the slides, but can't have the light-bulb moment that connects the dots together during the exams. 

In the earlier portions of the class, I also felt slightly uncomfortable when the professor made comments about how India is decades behind the US and (a direct quote from the slide) "India today is as rich as the US in 1880." Maybe this comment might be right in a strictly economic sense, or through GDP calculation, but it just gives a grossly wrong impression to students that the US is somehow more "advanced" than a country like India. Especially with the comment about India today being like the US in 1880, it just gives a wrong perception about how societies in developing countries exist right now. In addition, we also take as given how the lack of TFP, or the lack of capital in particular countries make them "less" than the US, which consistently occupies the number 1 spot in our development accounting models (so all countries are analyzed in comparison to the US, perhaps reflecting how US-centric the field of economics is). But, the question is: what made these countries lack TFP/capital to be able to achieve a level of long-run growth like the US? Even though it's a macro lecture, some insertion of economic history, such as the impact of colonialism on the lack of TFP/capital in developing countries, e.g. Daron Acemoglu's research on the impact of colonialism on economic institutions, or Melissa Dell's research on the persistent effects of Peru's forced mining labor system, can give a more balanced perspective. Perhaps this is a broader critique of economics as a whole, but I hope that these small adjustments can be made.

Strengths: detailed lectures, good sections, approachable material. 

Weaknesses: exam questions were often unnecessarily algebraically complicated versions of past homework problems or unnecessarily simplified (to the point of confusion)

Professor Peters is honestly one of the best professors I have ever had. He is a very engaging lecturer who explains all the material very clearly and poses questions to the class to encourage participation/discussion. He also always tries to connect the material to the real world by providing examples (for example, he starts each class with a news article that relates to macroeconomics). The psets/exams were also very fair (except for the final, which I found to be very hard). We did the psets 1 week behind the lecture, which meant that once we started the pset, we had already finished learning the material for the pset, which was helpful. I also had a great TA (John) who explained concepts very well and did example questions in class. Therefore, the psets were not too challenging.

It's a great class for finetuning economic intuitions and learning to make theory-grounded arguments about real-world data. Please use more rigorous math (even just a wider use of basic calculus would make things simpler and more elegant). Also, the professor isn't the best lecturer, and he poorly understands what we already know. For example, he'll ask the simplest question and then sit there for 5 minutes before someone gives the answer everyone already knew to begin with. Not a huge deal though, and overall still a good class.

This course could be GREATLY improved by the provision of lecture notes by the professor. The professor said he would have lecture notes IN ADDITION to slides in his syllabys, but only provided slides for students. As the slides were not very detailed, I would sometimes spend hours confused/trying to glean information from the slides. If there were comprehensive lecture notes in addition, I would have wasted much less time trying to figure out what the professor was trying to say in his slides. I would have appreciated the professor honoring the syllabus.

The course is super interesting in my opinion. I love the content. Course is challenging in that it is just really hard. Psets often take you way outside your comfort zone of what was discusses in class, as well as lecture. But that made it all the more fun to conquer.

The lack of TA office hours in the beginning of the semester was a hindrance to completing the problem sets. Moreover, the exams were constructed in such a way that error propagation was not taken into account for grading and the core concepts of the course were not tested so much as algebraic derivations.
I wish there was greater standardization of grading of problem sets.
The lectures were a little hard to follow at times, and I wish the slides were more detailed.
Professor was very good at explaining concepts, but I wish he focused on the math a little more.

The strengths include the structure of the lectures and how Professor Peters progresses the class through macroeconomic theory before taking the last few lectures to talk about disparity and poverty--two very important topics that often get neglected. Some of the weaknesses include the setting of the lecture in Sudler Hall, where is is often dark and where noise does not travel well. This makes it somewhat hard to be fully engaged in a long lecture at times.
The information was clear and well-structured. I found the lectures to be slow-moving in comparison to other economics courses I have taken.

After close to a half-dozen courses in the econ department, this course made me realize how badly the econ foundation sequence needs to be overhauled at Yale. I feel like I learned conceptually very little in this course, mostly just some extra bells and whistles on the same models from intro macro. The material is not taught in an interesting or memorable manner, and the psets are mostly about solving proofs and doing Excel busywork rather than applying the content in interesting ways. Professor Peters is a savvy and thoughtful professor, and the fact that even he can't figure out how to teach this content in an engaging way is a serious sign that the content itself needs to be changed. I think the econ department should spend some serious time re-evaluating which concepts are worthy of being included in this course.
Strengths: Professor Peters is a fantastic lecturer.
Yes. Interesting and relevant to real life.
Yes, and definitely take it with Prof Peters!
its a requirement for the major.

If you're an econ major - it's either this or macro theory so you really don't have options. If you want to learn about the macroeconomy as a non-econ major, I would take this over intro macro (you don't need the prerequisite, just show up).
It's required for the economics major.

I would recommend this course to another student but only if they are interested in becoming an economics major. While the math is not incredibly complex or challenging, it still is a major part of the class. If you are looking to build your economic intuition, then perhaps another class is better suited for you. This class, however, still taught me quite a lot and I am very happy that I decided to take it.
You probably should only take this class if you are an economics major.
I would recommend this course to Economics majors or people looking to study Economics after College.

If you are not an Economics major, this isn't the class for you. After taking the intro sequence, I wanted to learn more about economics even though I knew it wasn't going to be my major. This class introduced more advanced techniques but no new concepts that could lend the insight into the world of our economy that every citizen should have.

If you're an economics major, yes you need to take it.

If you just want to understand general macroeconomics, I recommend not skipping the introductory class, as you will be taking the class in Econ or Econ + Math majors who have far more econ experience than you otherwise.

Yes. Even though the final exam kind of destroyed me, this class is a fair one. Michael Peters and the teaching fellows (shout out to John Findlay) work hard to answer questions and to clarify confusing parts of the material. If you're going to be an Economics major, you'll have to take ECON 122, so you might as well take it with Michael Peters. He's a really endearing person, and you can tell he's got a passion for making the field of economics better with every lecture.

You would only take this course if you are deep in the economics sequence, but I would still recommend it because it is well-taught, interesting, and feels like you are learning about concepts that have relevance to the world
Yes, macroeconomics is a part of all of our lives. This class gives you a toolkit to understand the many moving pieces of our economy.

Yes definitely!! I know the micro/macro sequence in the econ major is usually very dry and people usually just want to get them over with. However, I really loved Intermediate Macroeconomics. It is much more interesting than microeconomics because you do less math (the occasional derivative) and you can see how the material you're learning can be applied to / connects to real world events. For me, I enjoy classes that are less theoretical and actually have real-world applications. This class also changed the way I view the world. For example, we attempted to answer many open-ended questions by learning the various models (are countries rich because they have more capital or tech or both? Why is the typical American 10 times richer today than 100 years ago? How did we escape the Malthusian trap? What caused the financial crisis in 2007? How does the Fed use monetary policy to affect the economy?) Therefore, I think the material we learned is incredibly important, even if you are not a econ major. It gives you better insight into how the world works. Professor Peters is also a really great professor.

It's an easy and fun class that will help you develop your knowledge of macro, and it's primarily useful for public policy students (or finance snakes, as the case may be). If you're at all interested in macro theory or prefer more rigor, I'd advise taking the math-intensive version.
